title-group.article-title: Fault-tolerant control design for near-space vehicles based on a dynamic terminal sliding mode technique

abstract.p: In this paper, a fault-tolerant control scheme based on a second-order dynamic terminal sliding mode is proposed for a near-space vehicle attitude dynamical system in the presence of actuator faults, model parameter uncertainties and external disturbances. The principle of the proposed dynamic terminal sliding mode scheme is firstly introduced. Then, a near-space vehicle attitude faulty model with parameter uncertainty is established. Furthermore, two dynamic terminal sliding mode controllers are designed for the inner and outer loops. It is shown that the proposed algorithm can reduce chattering phenomenon and guarantee system stability and asymptotic state tracking. Finally, simulation results are provided to demonstrate the performance of the proposed fault-tolerant control scheme.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Near-space vehicles (NSVs) are one kind of new aerospace vehicle that can sustain flight for a long time, with a high flight speed, and cover a wide range of characteristics, such as flight environment with thin density, high temperature and strong convection, so the NSV has a big flight envelope with fast changes of pneumatic parameters and strong disturbances. All the above-mentioned factors can lead to actuator or sensor faults in the aircraft, which inevitably affect NSV attitude control, flight stability, reliability and security. Therefore, the realization of fault-tolerant control (FTC) for faults is rather important and of practical significance in the aerospace industry.1,2At present, FTC methods3–7 can generally be classified in two types: active and passive fault tolerant. Both applications in the aerospace industry have some novel results, see, for example, Gao et al.,8 Xu et al.,9 Hu and Xiao,10 Cai et al.,11 Gao et al.,12 Peng et al.,13 Gao et al.,14 and the references therein. In the work of Gao et al.8 and Xu et al.,9 the active FTC method was used for fault diagnosis, isolation and estimation. A passive fault-tolerant controller was designed by Hu and Xiao10 to successfully achieve the attitude tracking control. An indirect robust adaptive fault-tolerant approach was employed to achieve attitude tracking control under a fault generated from the engine by Cai et al.11

Sliding mode control1,2 is an important method to solve nonlinear system issues due to its many excellent characteristics, such as simple design, high precision control and strong robustness with respect to system internal perturbations and external disturbances. A traditional sliding mode control adopts a linear switching function, which can guarantee the stability of the system; however, the system and system error converge to an equilibrium point, which needs a great deal of time, even to infinity. The terminal sliding mode switching function adopts a nonlinear function that can ensure the system and system error converge to equilibrium with in a finite time. The terminal sliding mode method was applied by Pu et al.15 for autopilot lethal unmanned aircraft and missiles, and obtained perfect control effects. A time-varying sliding mode control technique16 was proposed for reusable launch vehicles (RLV) attitude control in ascent and entry flight phases. However, the chattering phenomenon still existed. In the work of Hu et al.17 and Lin et al.,18 the terminal sliding mode was combined with the second dynamic sliding mode, which can make the designed system track desired signals within less time and greatly eliminated chattering phenomenon. Due to the advantages of a combination of a high-order dynamic sliding mode and terminal sliding, in this paper, FTC based on a second-order dynamic terminal sliding mode (DTSM) is designed for NSVs under actuator faults, external disturbances and model uncertainties, which can quickly and accurately track desired signals within a finite time. Meanwhile, the proposed second-order DTSM can effectively overcome the chattering phenomenon.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, the principle of second-order DTSM is introduced. The mathematical model of NSVs and problem formulation are then presented in the following section. The attitude tracking control is designed, and its effectiveness in dealing with modelling uncertainties, external disturbances and actuators faults is demonstrated in the following section, and the simulation results are provided to demonstrate the superiorities of the method over some existing work. Finally, the paper is concluded.

sec.title: Second-order DTSM
sec.p:
In order to keep the system moving on the sliding mode surface, the input switches on different controllers of the traditional sliding mode move backwards and forwards, which leads to chattering phenomena. The terminal dynamic sliding mode and the high-order sliding mode can solve the problem well.19,20 The high-order sliding mode not only makes the switching function equal to zero, it also makes its first derivative until its
r − 1
derivative zero.17,18 The controller designed using the high-order sliding mode only has the role on its derivative
r
of switching function, namely, the
r
-order sliding mode. The dynamic sliding mode method regains a new switching function via the redesign of a new switching function or a differential traditional switching function.21 The new switching function is generally relative to the system control input of first-order or a higher order derivative. Moreover, the discontinuous item of control can be embedded into its higher order derivative, consequently, we get the essence of a continuous dynamic sliding mode control law, which greatly reduces the chattering phenomenon. In addition, the terminal sliding mode can greatly improve the convergence rate by adopting a nonlinear function in the design of a sliding hyper plane.22 So in this paper, DTSM surfaces are proposed and DTSM controllers are designed.

sec.p: For the purpose of comparison, the corresponding simulation results are depicted in Figures 3, 6 and 9 using the method proposed by Jia and Quan,24 while Figures 2, 4, 5, 7, 8 and 10 use the approach provided in this paper.

Figures 2, 5 and 8 show NSV tracking trajectories under fault-free case 1 using the method in this paper, and indicate that all of the responses of control torque, angular velocity and attitude angle can track the desired objectives well. Furthermore, the DTSM algorithm can make the system stable within 10 s.

It can be easily seen from Figures 3, 6 and 9 that the time responses of the control torque, angular velocity and attitude angle become unstable quickly as soon as the actuator fault occurs at 30 s. However, compared with the method of Jia and Quan,24 from Figures 4, 7 and 10, we can obtain the results that all of the responses of control torque, angular velocity and attitude angle can be stable within 15 s, at most 20 s; furthermore, attitude angles tracking can be quickly stable about at 45 s as actuator
u
1
has a fault at 30 s, which can be compensated successfully and effectively via our proposed FTC algorithm. However, the responses of attitude tracking using the method proposed by Jia and Quan24 cannot reach the desired control objectives. From the simulation results, it can be seen clearly that our proposed scheme is much more tolerant to fault, and it can also obtain better dynamic performances.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, a second-order DTSM control scheme is proposed for NSVs. The proposed DTSM technique is applied to an NSV attitude system in the presence of actuator faults, inner parameter uncertainties and outer disturbances. Moreover, an auxiliary system is introduced such that the state of the auxiliary system can rapidly and accurately track the desired signals. Finally, the simulation results show that the proposed second-order DTSM method can guarantee that the desired attitude signals can be tracked well within finite time, and also that chattering phenomenon can be eliminated. In future work, the adaptive method will be introduced for on-line estimation of the boundaries of faults, which will be able to more accurately track the attitude angle commands under fault occurrence cases.
